properties.name: Advice
properties.location: Brunswick, Brunswick East, Carlton North, Fitzroy North, Princes Hill, Coburg, Northcote, Parkville, Thornbury
properties.webBody:
This Advice message is being issued for Brunswick, Brunswick East, Carlton North, Coburg, Fitzroy North, Northcote, Parkville, Princes Hill, Thornbury.
  • The Threat is Reduced following the factory fire in John Road, Brunswick East. 
  • This Advice replaces the Advice Message issued at 1.20PM.
  • You may see or smell smoke in the area for some time.
People located within the area are now able to resume normal activities.
What you should do: 
  • Traffic in the area will still be be affected as fire crews will be on scene into the evening.
  • Emergency services will remain in the area.
This message was issued by Fire Rescue Victoria.   

This will be the final message issued for this fire.

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au 
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226 
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfires) 
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV. 

Accessibility: 
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency. 
  • To access this information in other languages, call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.   
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.
properties.text:
ADVICE - STRUCTURE FIRE - Threat is Reduced
Incident Location: John St, Brunswick East
Issue Date: Friday 08 April 2022, 07:28 am
Next Update: Friday 08 April 2022, 12:30 pm

More details at http://emergency.vic.gov.au/respond/#!/warning/20648/moreinfo


This Advice message is being issued for Brunswick, Brunswick East, Carlton North, Coburg, Fitzroy North, Northcote, Parkville, Princes Hill, Thornbury.-         The Threat is   Reduced following the factory fire in John Road, Brunswick East. 
- This Advice replaces the Advice Message issued at 1.20PM.
- You may see or smell smoke in the area for some time.



People located within the area are now able to resume normal activities.

properties.name: Advice
properties.webBody:
This Minor Flood Warning is being issued for Buchan River.

RENEWED RISES EXPECTED AND MINOR FLOODING LIKELY AROUND MCKILLOPS BRIDGE THURSDAY

The Snowy River around of McKillop's Bridge remains close to the minor flood level Thursday. Renewed rises above the minor flood level are expected around McKillop's Bridge during Thursday and Friday due to rainfall observed overnight Wednesday and forecast for the remainder of Thursday.

Renewed rises are likely downstream of Basin Creek during Thursday but are expected to remain below the minor flood level.

In the 24 hours since 9:00 am Wednesday, 5-15 mm of rainfall were recorded in the upper and middle Snowy River catchment, with up to 5 mm recorded in downstream areas around Orbost and Buchan. A further 5-10 mm is forecast in the middle and upper parts of the catchment for the reminder of Thursday.

Buchan River:
Renewed rises below the minor flood level (2.50 m) are likely during Thursday.The Buchan River at Buchan is currently at 1.91 metres and steady.

Bombala River:
River levels are below the minor flood level (3.0 m) at Bombala. Renewed river rises below the minor floodlevel are expected along the Bombala River from Thursday afternoon.
The Bombala River at Bombala is currently at 1.53 metres and steady.
Stay informed - monitor your local conditions and remain alert.
What you should do: 

  • Be prepared to act if your situation changes.
  • You should stay informed by listening to emergency broadcasters and monitoring warnings.
  • Monitor weather forecasts and river levels online by visiting www.bom.gov.au/vic/warnings.
  • Floodwater is dangerous - never drive, walk or ride through floodwater.
Impacts in your area: 

  • High river levels and potential flooding in areas close to rivers and streams.
  • Some roads and bridges may still be closed as water levels drop.
  • Debris, trees and other hazards may be present following flooding.
  • Recent rainfall has increased the risk of landslides - be aware of fallen earth, rocks, debris and trees.
This message was issued by State Emergency Service.

The next update is expected by 08/04/2022 11:00 am or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfloods)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.

Accessibility: 
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency. 
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline. 
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.name: Advice
properties.location: Snowy River downstream of McKillops Bridge
properties.webBody:
This Minor Flood Warning is being issued for Snowy River downstream of McKillops Bridge.

RENEWED RISES EXPECTED AND MINOR FLOODING LIKELY AROUND MCKILLOPS BRIDGE THURSDAY  

The Snowy River around of McKillop's Bridge remains close to the minor flood level Thursday. Renewed rises above the minor flood level are expected around McKillop's Bridge during Thursday and Friday due to rainfall observed overnight Wednesday and forecast for the remainder of Thursday.

Renewed rises are likely downstream of Basin Creek during Thursday but are expected to remain below theminor flood level.

In the 24 hours since 9:00 am Wednesday, 5-15 mm of rainfall were recorded in the upper and middle Snowy River catchment, with up to 5 mm recorded in downstream areas around Orbost and Buchan. A further 5-10 mm is forecast in the middle and upper parts of the catchment for the reminder of Thursday.

Snowy River downstream of McKillops Bridge:
Renewed rises below the minor flood level are expected along the Snowy River downstream of McKillops Bridge.
The Snowy River Downstream Basin Creek is currently at 3.36 metres and steady. The Snowy River Downstream  Basin Creek  may exceed the minor flood level (3.50 m) Thursday afternoon and remain around the minor flood level overnight Thursday into Friday.
The Snowy River at Jarrahmond is currently at 3.16 metres and steady. The Snowy River at Jarrahmond islikely to remain below the minor flood level (4.10 m) during Thursday.
The Snowy River at Orbost is currently at 3.50 metres and steady. The Snowy River at Orbost is likely toremain below the minor flood level (4.20 m) during Thursday.

Bombala River:
River levels are below the minor flood level (3.0 m) at Bombala. Renewed river rises below the minor floodlevel are expected along the Bombala River from Thursday afternoon.
The Bombala River at Bombala is currently at 1.53 metres and steady.

Stay informed - monitor your local conditions and remain alert.

There may be debris over roads and delays to your usual access routes due to flood waters. 
What you should do: 

  • Farmers should consider moving livestock and machinery to higher ground.
  • Monitor weather forecasts and river levels online by visiting www.bom.gov.au/vic/warnings.
  • Floodwater is dangerous - never drive, walk or ride through floodwater.
Impacts in your area: 
  • The Princes Highway has re-opened in both directions.
  • High river levels and potential flooding in areas close to rivers and streams.
  • Local roads may be closed and low bridges may be underwater.
This message was issued by State Emergency Service.

The next update is expected by 08/04/2022 11:00 am or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfloods)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.

Accessibility: 
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency. 
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline. 
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

cap.senderName: Department of Environment, Land, Water & Planning

properties.name: Community Information
properties.webBody:
This message is being issued for water quality at Barwon Heads. 

  • High levels of Blue Green Algae have been detected in the Lake Connewarre and the lower reaches of the Barwon River near Barwon Heads.
  • The algal bloom is expected to remain until there is significant rainfall to flush the lake or cooler conditions slow the algae. 
  • Warnings signs have been installed at various locations, people should avoid direct contact with the water until the algal bloom disperses. 
  • The Department of Environment, Land, Water and Planning (DELWP) /Barwon Coast Committee of Management and Parks Victoria will continue monitoring the Barwon River near Barwon Heads and Lake Connewarre until the bloom disperses and will advise when the river and lake is safe for use again.
You should avoid direct contact with affected water in Lake Connewarre and the lower reaches of the Barwon River.

Do not swim in affected areas or use water for cooking, drinking, washing or showering. Boiling the water will not make it safe. 
What you should do:
  • Visit https://www.health.vic.gov.au/water/health-effects-of-blue-green-algae for more information. 
  • Observe information signs posted at various locations. 

Protect your health:
  • Direct contact with water affected by blue green algae can cause skin irritation, sore eyes, ears and nose. If swallowed it can cause cramps, nausea and vomiting. 
  • If you do come into contact with affected water, wash your skin immediately in clean cool water. 
  • Boiling affected water does not make it safe to drink. Boiling water bursts the blue green algae cells and releases toxins into the water making it more likely that you will experience symptoms. 
  • If you are experiencing any health issues after contact with affected water seek medical advice from your local doctor or Nurse-On-Call on 1300 60 60 24.

Protect your pets:
  • Pet owners should prevent pets from drinking or having direct contact with contaminated water. 
Impacts in your area:
  • The water is green as a result of the algae bloom.

Boating and fishing:
  • Recreational activities in the river should be avoided, which includes swimming and boating.
  • Any fish harvested from the river and lake must have the gills and guts removed prior to cooking. 
  • People should not eat whole fish, or shellfish or crustaceans collected from Lake Connewarre or the Barwon River.
  • The type of algae affecting Lake Connewarre and the Barwon River produces toxins that can concentrate in shellfish and crustaceans and accumulate in the liver and internal organs of fish. Ingesting BGA toxins can lead to serious illness.

This message was issued by Department of Environment, Land, Water & Planning.

The next update is expected by 14/04/2022 12:00 pm or as the situation changes.

Information about blue green algae:
  • For information on blue green algae visit: https://www.health.vic.gov.au/water/blue-green-algae-cyanobacteria.
  • For information on blue green algae and stock visit: https://agriculture.vic.gov.au/farm-management/water/blue-green-algae-in-water/managing-bluegreen-algae-in-farm-water-supplies
  • For information on blue green algae and irrigation visit: https://agriculture.vic.gov.au/farm-management/water/blue-green-algae-in-water/bluegreen-algae-and-irrigation-water

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter
  • Tune into ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
properties.text:
COMMUNITY INFORMATION - BLUE GREEN ALGAE
Incident Location: Barwon River and Lake Connewarre
Issue Date: Saturday 19 March 2022, 12:58 pm
Next Update: Thursday 14 April 2022, 12:00 pm

More details at http://emergency.vic.gov.au/respond/#!/warning/20405/moreinfo

This message is being issued for water quality at Barwon Heads. 

- High levels of Blue Green Algae have been detected in the Lake Connewarre and the lower reaches of the Barwon River near Barwon Heads.
- The algal bloom is expected to remain until there is significant rainfall to flush the lake or cooler conditions slow the algae. 
- Warnings signs have been installed at various locations, people should avoid direct contact with the water until the algal bloom disperses. 
- The Department of Environment, Land, Water and Planning (DELWP) /Barwon Coast Committee of Management and Parks Victoria will continue monitoring the Barwon River near Barwon Heads and Lake Connewarre until the bloom disperses and will advise when the river and lake is safe for use again.


You should avoid direct contact with affected water in Lake Connewarre and the lower reaches of the Barwon River.

Do not swim in affected areas or use water for cooking, drinking, washing or showering. Boiling the water will not make it safe.

properties.webBody:
This Minor Flood Warning is being issued for Snowy River to McKillops Bridge:

RENEWED RISES EXPECTED AND MINOR FLOODING LIKELY AROUND MCKILLOPS BRIDGE THURSDAY

The Snowy River around of McKillop's Bridge remains close to the minor flood level Thursday. Renewed rises above the minor flood level are expected around McKillop's Bridge during Thursday and Friday due torainfall observed overnight Wednesday and forecast for the remainder of Thursday.

Renewed rises are likely downstream of Basin Creek during Thursday but are expected to remain below theminor flood level.

In the 24 hours since 9:00 am Wednesday, 5-15 mm of rainfall were recorded in the upper and middle Snowy River catchment, with up to 5 mm recorded in downstream areas around Orbost and Buchan. A further 5-10 mm is forecast in the middle and upper parts of the catchment for the reminder of Thursday.

Snowy River to McKillops Bridge:
Renewed rises and minor flooding are likely along the Snowy River to McKillops Bridge.

The Snowy River at McKillops Bridge is currently at 2.44 metres and rising. The Snowy River at McKillops Bridge is likely to exceed the minor flood level (2.50 m) Thursday afternoon and is likely to remain above theminor flood level overnight Thursday into Friday.

Bombala River:
River levels are below the minor flood level (3.0 m) at Bombala. Renewed river rises below the minor floodlevel are expected along the Bombala River from Thursday afternoon.
The Bombala River at Bombala is currently at 1.53 metres and steady.
Stay informed - monitor your local conditions and remain alert.
What you should do: 

  • Farmers should consider moving livestock and machinery to higher ground.
  • Be prepared to act if your situation changes.
  • You should stay informed by listening to emergency broadcasters and monitoring warnings.
  • Floodwater is dangerous - never drive, walk or ride through floodwater.
  • Monitor weather forecasts and river levels online by visiting www.bom.gov.au/vic/warnings.
Impacts in your area: 

  • Local roads may be closed and low bridges may be underwater. 
  • High river levels and potential flooding in areas close to rivers and streams.
  • Local roads may be closed and low bridges may be underwater.
This message was issued by State Emergency Service.

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfloods)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
  • For road closure information go to www.traffic.vicroads.vic.gov.au or phone 13 11 70.

Accessibility: 
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency. 
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline. 
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

cap.senderName: Department of Environment, Land, Water & Planning

properties.name: Community Information
properties.webBody:
This message is being issued for water quality at Lake Bolac.

  • High levels of blue green algae have been detected in the lake. 
  • The algal bloom is expected to remain until there is significant rainfall to flush the lake or cooler conditions slow the algae. 
  • Regular testing is being conducted to identify new outbreaks or changes that might indicate improved water quality. 
  • This notification will be reviewed weekly and updated as the situation changes. 
Warning signs have been installed at the lake. 

You should avoid direct contact with affected water in Lake Bolac. 

Do not swim in affected areas or use water for cooking, drinking, washing or showering.  Boiling the water will not make it safe. 
What you should do:
  • Visit Parks Victoria website for more information. 
  • Observe information signs posted at the Lake Bolac.

Protect your health:
  • Direct contact with water affected by blue green algae can cause skin irritation, sore eyes, ears and nose. If swallowed it can cause cramps, nausea and vomiting. 
  • If you do come into contact with affected water, wash your skin immediately in clean cool water. 
  • Boiling affected water does not make it safe to drink. Boiling water bursts the blue green algae cells and releases toxins into the water making it more likely that you will experience symptoms. 
  • If you are experiencing any health issues after contact with affected water seek medical advice from your local doctor or Nurse-On-Call on 1300 60 60 24.

Protect your pets:
  • Pet owners should prevent pets from drinking or having direct contact with contaminated water. 

Agriculture information: 
  • Irrigation water contaminated with blue green algae should not be spray irrigated on vegetables and fruit, or come in contact with plants being grown for food during processing and packing. 
  • Fruit and vegetables grown in the affected areas are safe to consume if farmers follow recommendations regarding blue green algae.
Impacts in your area:
  • The water is  green as a result of the algae bloom.

Boating and fishing:
  • Boating and fishing is still allowed in these areas, however care needs to be taken.
  • Fish caught from affected areas should be rinsed and cleaned thoroughly in fresh water, and internal organs removed from the fish and discarded before eating. 
  • Do not eat mussels, crayfish or yabbies caught from the affected area. 

This message was issued by Department of Environment, Land, Water & Planning.

The next update is expected by 26/04/2022 05:50 pm or as the situation changes.

Information about blue green algae:
  • For information on blue green algae visit: www2.health.vic.gov.au/public-health/water/blue-green-algae-cyanobac teria.
  • For information on blue green algae and stock visit: http://agriculture.vic.gov.au/agriculture/pests-diseases-and-weeds/animal-diseases/beef-and-dairy-cows/blue-green-algal -poisoning-of-stock.
  • FOr information on blue green algae and irrigation visit: http://agriculture.vic.gov.au/agriculture/farm-management/soil-and-water/irrigation/blue-green-algae-and-irrigation-water.

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au.
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226.
  • VicEmergency app.
  • Facebook or Twitter.
  • Tune into ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.

Do not swim in affected areas or use water for cooking, drinking, washing or showering.  Boiling the water will not make it safe.
